Anki/Getting-Started.title: Getting Started
Anki/Getting-Started.content:
How to Use Anki: An Efficient Tutorial for Beginners
Weâ€™re going to cover ONLY the most essential elements of Anki that you should focus on, so you can:

Immediately start using this awesome spaced repetition software
Avoid the same mistakes that I did; and
Have a roadmap that tells you whatâ€™s actually important when using Anki

Capabilities of Anki
If you donâ€™t know already, here are a couple of things Anki allows you to do in a nutshell:

Schedule reviews automatically, so you donâ€™t have to worry about which specific topic to study
Study 1714.29% more efficiently as compared to those using conventional flashcards
Study only what needs studying
Encode information into long term memory at will, rather than by chance
Remember almost anything you want without having to re-read
Study anywhere! Studying felt less effortful than ever the moment I started using Anki before. What a blessing.

Now, this guide exists because I believe you just need to learn the few core info if youâ€™re just looking to start.
Itâ€™s much like learning how to drive a car:

You donâ€™t start driving a car by studying the ENTIRE manual. You only need to get better at using the ESSENTIAL controls to be able to start driving it.

Real Talk: What is Anki? How does it work?
As you may know, Anki is an open-source flashcard app that uses spaced repetition algorithms to help you prevent natural forgetting.
Even if youâ€™re not born with awesome recall skills, Anki can help you toÂ intentionally commit information into long-term memory.
But thereâ€™s a caveat.
That is, Anki works by supplementing your study process.
As good as it is, itâ€™s NOT a magic pill nor a substitute for poor learning skills.
Why? Because Anki covers just the final one-third of the memoryâ€™s core processes for information encoding. â€” which is retrieval.
This means that if the first two-thirds of the system you use for studying â€” encoding & storage â€” is messed up, then using Anki wonâ€™t be the magic pill that itâ€™s believed to be.
In contrast, when you do use Anki with the right process, you could gain tremendous advantage over the competition:

You basically guarantee that anything you study (again, using the right process) WILL get remembered for a long time.
You build up a tall stack of prior knowledge that allows you to understand complex concepts quickly.
You eliminate the most time-wasting study activity of all â€” â€œrestudying what youâ€™ve already studied because you forgotâ€
You can turn downtime into productive study time (when you use Anki while eating, for example, it allows you to practice 50 items in a breeze)

Best of all, you get a tremendous long-term efficiency benefit:
Michael Nielsen mentioned that in 20 years, he is 1714.29% (120 minutes/7 minutes * 100%) more efficient for each card when learning using spaced repetition compared to conventional flashcard learning.
Sound good so far? Iâ€™m hearing questionsâ€¦
â€œIsnâ€™t Anki just good for memorizing small facts?â€
Contrary to popular belief, just because Anki is a flashcard app doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s only used for memorizing words or raw facts.
As I imply in the last section, Anki is also a tool for LEARNING â€” which means it helps you establish a â€œlibrary of mental modelsâ€ for understanding higher-level concepts.
I never skip Anki because in my mind, if I donâ€™t retain all the prerequisite knowledge Iâ€™m required to remember, then itâ€™d be hard for me to understand higher-level concepts in the future. (Ultimately, this causes even more wasted time.)
â€œIf Anki is so effective, then why do so many people fail at using it?â€
Why do SO MANY people go into flashcard hell?
Glad you asked. A few reasons why:

They use shared decks (most of which are ineffective). They keep trying to remember what they havenâ€™t even learned yet. Learn before you memorize!
They have an unwieldy deck structure. Donâ€™t create artificial knowledge barriers! As a rule of thumb, you should have one deck for each retrieval context. (exam, interview, language, field, etc.) NOT a deck for every section or topic of a book!
Intermittent Reviews. They do Anki reviews intermittentlyâ€”as if natural forgetting can be â€œskipped.â€
Their thinking is stuck in Anki and ignore the other 2/3 of the learning process. They functionally fix themselves into Anki â€” they see it as â€œthe entire systemâ€ when really, itâ€™s really just â€œa small part of the engineâ€. Learning skills matter.

Note: Iâ€™m well aware that you can use shared decks effectively for standardized exams, but I really donâ€™t recommend it â€” UNLESS youâ€™re in Medical School. I know of people whoâ€™ve created and used high-quality shared decks with great success, and you can find them here.
Thing is, most of these people who fail at using Anki treat is as a magic pill, instead of a tool that requires skill. (Woah, that rhymedâ€¦)
As Michael Nielsen put it in his essay:

Anki is an extremely simple program [â€¦] Despite that simplicity, itâ€™s an incredibly powerful tool. And, like many tools, it requires skill to use well. Itâ€™s worth thinking of Anki as a skill that can be developed to virtuoso levels, and attempting to continue to level up toward such virtuosity.

Creating your first Anki cards
To create cards, just hit the â€œAddâ€ on the top part of your window.

By clicking on it, you should be seeing the Add New window containing (1) Type, (2) Deck, (3) Front and Back fields, and (4) Tag field.

Now, I wouldnâ€™t worry about the â€œFieldsâ€¦â€ and â€œCardsâ€¦â€ buttons just yet. Theyâ€™re just card customizations that donâ€™t make any difference at all to your recall.
Like I said at the beginning of this guide, this is supposed to be about the essentials â€” and theyâ€™re just ainâ€™t it.
So donâ€™t even think that you need them.
Trust me, youâ€™ll get VERY FAR without even touching those things.
Now, in the â€œAdd Newâ€ window, the question goes in â€œFrontâ€ and the answer goes in â€œBackâ€ field, just like your good olâ€™ paper flashcards.

Once youâ€™ve entered your desired Question and Answer pair, you can click on â€œAddâ€ or just use the shortcut â€œCtrl + Enterâ€ or â€œCmd + Enterâ€ to make the card.

Note: Make sure to DOUBLE CHECK the â€œDeckâ€ field before adding the card to prevent future headaches.
By the way, the card youâ€™ve just seen is one of the â€œBasicâ€ Card Types.

Yes, there are a few card types â€” but remember that the principle here is still to help yourself review information through recall.
The â€œBasicâ€ card type allows you to perform the traditional flashcard studying â€” Question in front, Answer at the back.
The Cloze deletion, on the other hand, is a â€œfill-in-the-blankâ€ type of card.
The others are self-explanatory based on their name.
Question, foreseen: Which Anki card types are the best for learning?
YES. The answer is yesâ€¦but Iâ€™ll explain.
The best card type is the one that has the best fit for the information you have learned.
And guess what? The most flexible way to do that (without sacrificing the quality of learning) is by making Q&A cards with a Basic card type.
Iâ€™m speaking from experience, too: Cloze and reversed cards are hard to pull off unless you know how to create quality cards.
So my advice to you is to practice creating questions and answers first using a Basic card type. Only create Cloze cards for things that cannot be answered through recognition memory.
In short, start with only using Basic cards. Worry about the others once you can already make that work for you.

Organizing your cards
Like I said earlier, I like to use Tags instead of subdecks.
Why tags? Because it simplifies everything. You need not worry about creating subdecks for each subject because you can use â€œCustom Studyâ€ more selectively later on.
You can add Tags to your cards in two ways:

During Card Creation, or
Using the Card Browser

I recommend adding Tags during Card Creation â€” itâ€™s much faster and more proactive.
To add Tags during card creation, you just enter the name of your desired Tag on the â€œTagsâ€ field of the Add New window.

Hereâ€™s something to remember: Replace spaces with underscores.
Note: If you missed that and accidentally entered two words separated by spaces, youâ€™ll be creating TWO tags for your cards, not one.
Now, creating that card, you should notice that the Tag name you entered in the Tags field did not go away.
This means you can create and create several cards without having to worry about putting Tags in every single timeâ€”thatâ€™s pretty handy.
The second method of adding tags is via the Card Browser. You open it up by clicking on â€œBrowseâ€ on the Home Screen or pressing â€œBâ€ in the same place.

Hereâ€™s how:

Click on a deck where you can find the to-be-tagged cards
Select your cards on the right-hand side (you can select multiple)
Right-click, then go to Notes > Add Tags

)
I donâ€™t prefer this method because itâ€™s rather easy to mess this up.
Imagine accidentally adding tags to other cards when you already have a large collection of cards â€” just thinking about organizing it is already a disaster.
But, you do what you wanna do ğŸ™‚
Hereâ€™s How I Make Anki Flashcards
When youâ€™re creating your cards, IMO the best way to create high-quality cards is to have these elements in place:

A specific question
A specific answer
Screenshot of source
Tags (optional)

You should be good as long as you have those.
To demonstrate, Iâ€™ll be using a random book from the medical field (a field I donâ€™t know anything about) just to demonstrate this process from a beginner standpoint.
So, when I see something on my book like this:

This card below is the one I make. I included the Question, Answer, Screenshot, and Tag.

PRO TIP: You can add new lines to the â€œBackâ€ field if you want to add more details such as mnemonics or screenshots.
Notice that I italicized and bolded the word â€œpreviouslyâ€ to show emphasis. Itâ€™s a way to make a cue for an answer more salient and easier to process.
Letâ€™s look at the card preview.

Looks awesome!
By the way, I want to tell you that for dense conceptual subjects, I break each concept down into more questions that test my understanding.
And this requires that I understand the thing FIRST.
This is the iron rule of effective card-makingâ€¦
Learn first before you memorize! (Rules #1 and #2 in the classic Twenty Rules of Formulating Knowledge)
Facts are good to include as cards, for sure. But you have to encourage your understanding of the material â€” otherwise youâ€™ll end up doing rote memorization. Youâ€™ll end up with a LOT of knowledge that you cannot even use.
A pro tip from me:
You can also simulate situations that use the concept itself so you donâ€™t miss out on actually applying what you have learned.
See this card, for example:
)
See how that works?
Alright, letâ€™s move on to what you need to remember when creating new cards.
Tips for Creating Good Anki Flashcards
1 â€“ Learn FIRST, and THEN create flashcards from what youâ€™ve learned
Just like what I said a while ago, you gotta learn first before you make your cards.
If youâ€™re just starting out, all you need to know is that the purpose of these flashcards is to test what you already learned.
Folks, itâ€™s â€œremember what you learnâ€œ, and not â€œlearn what you rememberâ€œ.
Itâ€™s easy to get confident that you can remember anything using Anki, but the truth is that NONE of that matters if you do not understand the material youâ€™re putting in.
(Unless youâ€™re really memorizing isolated facts, but even so, context matters for retention)
Well, whatâ€™s the worst that could happen when you donâ€™t follow this rule?
Youâ€™ll know how to answer the flashcard but youâ€™ll find out that you cannot apply the â€œknowledgeâ€ anywhere else.
In other words, you just get pseudoknowledge.
2 â€“ One simple card is worth 2x the vague cards
Donâ€™t try to put in paragraphs in a card.
Donâ€™t even try to put â€œExplainâ€ type of questions.
Break them down until itâ€™s simple FOR YOU.
This brings me to my next point.
3 â€“ The number of cards donâ€™t matter much; coverage matters more
Thereâ€™s no optimal number of cards.
Think about whatâ€™s important here: Itâ€™s important that you have made cards that can cover the entire material youâ€™ve understood.
So when adding cards, it doesnâ€™t matter if you have plenty of cards just by studying a chapter as long as you follow the two rules above.
What matters is you actually learn the concepts thoroughly.
Break a concept as much as possible.
By doing these two things, youâ€™ll feel like youâ€™re able to recall each card in less than a second. (Well, not physically less than a second, but thatâ€™s how itâ€™ll feel like ğŸ˜‰)
Itâ€™s much, much faster compared to creating a few but long, complicated cards.
For example, instead of:
â€œWhat are Newtonâ€™s Three Laws of Motion?â€
You write questions like:

â€œWhat is Newtonâ€™s First Law of Motion?â€
â€œWhat is Newtonâ€™s Third Law of Motion?â€
â€œWhich law states F=ma?â€ (obviously, this question covers one law in another angle â€” also called redundancy)

This reduces ambiguity â€” making your cards faster to answer. Compare that to doing a mini-brain dump for each card and youâ€™ll realize it gets tiresome pretty quickly.
Just to be clear, thereâ€™s no stopping you from creating both types of cards.
Feel free to experiment, because there really are times when a longer card can be more efficient. Letâ€™s avoid black-and-white thinking here.
Still not sure how to properly structure your flashcards?
Well, in that case, I made a quick reference of examples just for you.
This quick reference will show you 13 flashcard examples and anti-examples so you can get started making good flashcards and avoid creating bad ones.
Specifically, youâ€™re going to discover some of theÂ most important lessonsÂ Iâ€™ve gainedÂ fromÂ manuallyÂ creating 4000+ flashcards:

You can click the red button below to go to the signup page.
How to use Anki for studying anywhere (without feeling like youâ€™re studying)
Head over to Anki Sign Up and register for an account. Itâ€™s totally free. Thatâ€™s why Damien Elmes is a hero.
Then, after creating an account, press â€˜Syncâ€™ on your Ankiâ€™s home screen.

A dialog box requiring your details will pop up.
Simply enter the details you signed up for at AnkiWeb, and this will allow automatic syncing of your deck to the AnkiWeb serversâ€”which allows you to sync your cards to ALL devices.
Itâ€™s pretty neat, especially if youâ€™re going outside with your smartphone. (or when youâ€™re sitting on the toilet â€” not exactly neat, tho)
When youâ€™re waiting in line, or just doing nothing at all, instead of scrolling through Facebook, you can answer 5 to 20 cards in a minute, depending on how good you create cards.
That means youâ€™re converting idle time into STUDYING.
If that isnâ€™t called studying smart, I donâ€™t know what is.
You can turn it off and manually sync your cards by pressing Y on the home screen, but itâ€™s always a good idea to sync your cards automatically upon open/exit just to avoid forgetting.
Smash That Spacebar!
Studying using Anki is pretty straightforward.
You just open the app, click a deck with due cards, and youâ€™re set.
When a card shows up, you just press on the spacebar to show the answer.

When the answer shows up, you are given choices below to choose from: Again, Good, Easy.
Using Anki default settings, Anki will show the card again after a certain amount depending on how difficult it was for you to recall the card.

Again â€“ Less than a minute, the card will show up again
Good â€“ The card will show up in less than 10 minutes
Easy â€“ The card will show up after 4 days

My method is simple:

You press Again when you failed to recall the answer,
You press Good when you successfully recall the answer
You press Easy when you meet two things: you already know the answer a long time ago, and you have recalled the answer in an instant

You can use Answer Button shortcuts as shown below:

As a side note for default settings, pressing â€œAgainâ€ on a mature card for a total of 8 times makes your card â€œdisappearâ€ and not show up for review.
This is called a ==Leech card==, and is usually classified as a poorly created card.
When you get Leech cards, all you have to do is reformulate your questions. Again, refer back to how I told you to create flashcards.
Alright, now before I end this, I would like to give you some tips that would help you study smarter using Anki.
Why You Should NEVER Miss a Day of Review
Forgetting happens every single day. This means that poorly learned, seldomly used information are good as DELETED every single day.
Anki works to combat this effect. (But again, follow my tip#1 when creating cards)
Another reason not to skip is you end up with a mountain of cards the next day. Yup, now youâ€™ll have to review your overdue cards PLUS your due cards â€” thatâ€™s a hell of a review session to go through (trust me, Iâ€™ve been through 1500 cards in a day and I almost cried just doing that).
So, try do study every single day without fail.
Closing Thoughts: Anki is a great tool for studying â€” but itâ€™s not the entire study system
As powerful as Anki is, itâ€™s just a tool that depends on your skills â€” and I want to make sure I drive that point home.
Thereâ€™s always a sense of â€œwonderâ€ in exploring new tools especially when it promises to solve our problems with having the lack of time.
But my advice, from experience, is to look at efficiency a different way:
Instead of adding tools, think about eliminating wastes.
Thatâ€™s the purpose of tools in the first place â€” to help us eliminate effort that isnâ€™t adding any value or not leading us closer to our goal.
Anki eliminates the non-value-adding activity called â€œscheduling your reviews and worrying about whether you need to review each item today or not.â€ (Yeah, thatâ€™s a mouthful)
But do NOT, by any means, expect that itâ€™s a magic pill that will make you remember anything without skill and work ethic.
Whatâ€™s Next?

Download AnkiCollab addon ğŸŒ AnkiCollab

Anki/Setup-Subscriber.title: Setup Subscriber
Anki/Setup-Subscriber.content:
Getting Started - Subscriber
The subscription key ğŸ”‘ is all you need!
The key will be a series of words separated by dashes. Example:
pip-item-hawaii-skylark-network-rugby





















StudentSubscription KeyThanhecho-triple-fifteen-jig-jupiter-winneTLinhgee-floor-fifteen-jig-jupiter-winnerTrungitem-victor-fifteen-jig-jupiter-winner
Video Guide
If you prefer to watch a video, here is the latest guide:

Adding the Key to Anki


Open Anki.


On the toolbar, click AnkiCollab â†’ Edit Subscriptions.

This window will show all your current subscriptions.

Add a new deck by pasting it into the box at the bottom and clicking Add Subscription.

There will be a confirmation and you can now close this window.
The deck may not show up immediately! If you donâ€™t see the deck, click the Deck button at the top of the main Anki page to refresh ğŸ”„ the view.

If you see the title of the deck pop up, you are ready to start reviewing! ğŸ‘


Suggesting Changes
Card Content and Tags
Not every Anki deck is perfect â€” typos, content errors, strange formatting, or other issues might pop up. There might even be some errors in this very document that will get changed in the future!
One huge strength of AnkiCollab is the ability to let the maintainer know that there might be an issue with a deck.
âš  In this section, weâ€™ll be showing how to change a cardâ€™s content within the fields, but the process is identical for tags.
Letâ€™s say you subscribe to a deck and find this card:

Sure, elephants ğŸ˜ are big, but you know that the biggest animal in the world is actually a Blue Whale ğŸ³.
After double-checking that youâ€™re correct, change the word Elephant to Blue Whale in the same manner you would edit a normal card.
Once youâ€™ve edited the card, click the AnkiCollab button.

A small window will pop up and ask you to choose a rationale for making this change.

In our case, letâ€™s choose Content Error. Next, click OK.
Youâ€™ve now submitted your first change!
From the maintainerâ€™s point of view, theyâ€™ll see a window like this:

This page tells the maintainer what exactly was changed and why.
From here, they can approve or reject your suggestion. If approved, everyone who subscribed to this deck will receive an update with your change.
You are now ready to go into the AnkiCollab world and improve decks! ğŸ‘
New Cards
Some decks on AnkiCollab are unfinished, looking for people to contribute and finish them. In this case, you donâ€™t want to be editing cards, but adding new ones.
âš ï¸ Before you start adding cards, make sure you are adding them to the correct deck!
Letâ€™s say you subscribed to a Flower Identification deck, but theyâ€™re missing the California Poppy. When adding the card, all you have to do is check the Suggest on AnkiCollab button toward the bottom.

Now you just need to wait for the maintainer to approve your card!
Downloading Updates
To download any changes or new content for your subscribed deck, you can manually check for new content or automatically check for updates on startup.
Check for New Content Manually
On the toolbar, click AnkiCollab â†’ Check for New Content.

This will retrieve any available updates for your subscription.
If any updates are available, you will be shown the changelog and asked if you want to Install Now, Skip this Update, or Decide Later.

Check for New Content Automatically
On the toolbar, click AnkiCollab â†’ Settings â†’ Check for Updates on Startup.

When you startup Anki, AnkiCollab will automatically check for updates and prompt you to install any available updates.

Introduction.title: Introduction
Introduction.content:
Greetings, Family
Our class will begin this week, I hope that we will have a smooth sailing journey together.
A Personal Note
First, this is deeply personal for me, and I trusted you guys to keep this between us, so DO NOT share with anyone, okay? Even though itâ€™s on public domain :D
Typically, I would jot down these reflections in my journal but for this occasion, to motivate you guys, to hopefully ignite a flame of undying passion for learning, I would like to share a snapshot of my life. First, one of my early mottos:

My thirst for knowledge will never be quenched.
If you donâ€™t like it, then tough luck, take this as a reading task, and Iâ€™ve highlighted the vocabulary that youâ€™ve learned, not the new ones.
So, to mark the commencement of our learning endeavor, here are your first tasks:




                  
                  This week's tasks 
                  
                


  First-level of recursion for new words on this reading task.
 Your comments/remarks (at least 3), send me personally or via group chat, suit you.
 Extra 2 points for those who note grammar structures used as well. An exhaustive one.



âš ï¸Note  Minus 1 point for each vocabulary word you miss if asked. Missing means that you havenâ€™t noted it yet.
Autobiography
People often tell me how â€œa normal personâ€ would behave differently than I do, so I guess itâ€™s only reasonable that my school life wasnâ€™t typical either, lol.
Compared to my peers, I didnâ€™t study as much, playing most of the time and often doing the bare minimum or finding unconventional shortcuts to keep pace with them. But lucky me, the so-called â€œpeersâ€ were all geniuses, so I got put in place a lot. Even if I fooled around, the baseline level of effort to keep up helped me pass almost every important test entry.
My life has been the complete opposite and will probably become of this quote:

You either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.


Without any intervention, wandering with perplexity and curiosity, I turned into a bad, but meticulous kid that no one seemed to notice.


I believe the duality of oneâ€™s nature will always be present, but my poor decisions were taken lightly, or more accurately, went by unawares.
Iâ€™m not proud, but thankfully, I could get back on the right track without much of a fight.

Primary School
This period was what I called â€œA Dark Era,â€ a time filled with confusion and all sorts of emotions with no self-awareness and restraint.

I was a perfect role model student and, better yet, a bully.
Too sharp for my own good, excelling at anything I picked up, so naturally, I got things in my favor.
Peopleâ€™s attention and praise probably took a heavy toll on me, feeding an ego that I didnâ€™t know how to process, but that was no excuse. I was led astray, blinded by the rewards and recognition.

Maybe subtle blame for uncontrollable primal instinctsâ€”aggression, violence, and the desperate need for validation.ğŸ˜Œ
Letâ€™s not delve furtherâ€¦
Secondary School
The Muted Aftermath
A got-away-with-it-somehow spoiled brat ended up in the top class of the top secondary school. I came to my senses only much later on, back then I was still feigning ignorance and acting on impulse, as most children would.
Therefore, I got this uncalled-for luxury of going to school by taxiâ€”yep, a taxi, alongside my neighborhood friends. Truly a story to be bragging about, for bourgeois families.
The academic life went south from here ğŸ˜… as the impetuous desires got the better of me. I skipped classes more than I skipped meals.
I would told the cab driver to stop by the net on the way to school =))) and he would happily do so, since he was paid. Not my kid, not my problem ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ Gotta respect that attitude. Had a lot of fun and a lot of bad gradesâ€¦ Everything was on a downward spiral, yet funny enough, I never got caught or confronted.
Underappreciated Youth
I formed bonds with most of my closest friends here with the most unfiltered, raw, and rough version of myself. The same goes for them.
These low-maintenance relationships, I believe, will stay unstained, growing stronger yet unaffected by time and distance as it has always been.
We were not only in the best but also the wealthiest class. We could go on weekend trips if any of the generous parents were happy that their kid scored a 10. A local prize would almost guarantee a trip and a national one!? Weâ€™d have back-to-back class holidays! Without spending a dime.
This seemingly chill class turned out to have the highest unprecedented acceptance rate at Lam Son Gifted High School.
I doubt Iâ€™ll ever have as many extravagant field trips as I did back then. I got to see so much of Vietnamâ€™s beauty and historical richness â€” things I had long taken for granted.
But it wasnâ€™t just the scenes and places I overlooked; it was the people too. I discovered so many new emotionsâ€”ones that were pivotal, inevitable, but bitterishâ€”regret, sorrow, rage, and that heartbroken feeling, or whatever youâ€™d name it.
Most of these feelings were directed at myself: for the decisions I left unmade, for the precious people I failed to cherish until they quietly walked out of my life forever.
Though painful, these realizations became the compass points guiding my future path and were the turning point for me.
High School
Getting into Lam Son has been my most significant cornerstone, though I didnâ€™t realize it only until recently.
It wasnâ€™t the schoolâ€™s prestige or education (which, in and of itself, is remarkable) that made the differenceâ€”it was the people here who changed me for the better, forever.
My typical day here would start like this:

Iâ€™d wake up late and rush to school, couldnâ€™t make it on time, thinking â€œscrew it,â€ and go buy breakfast with extra, extra toppings, leisurely enjoying every bite.
I was the class secretary, so it was easy for me to make up a lot of excuses for my 15-to-30-minute tardiness. I did this so frequently that everyone gradually stopped questioning my legitimacy.
Getting away with it almost every time - the pinnacle of gaslighting, huh?

The daily inquiries were rather simple:

What should I eat next?
Where should we hang out after school?
Should we play Werewolves, Ribbit, or Exploding Kittens today?
What rhetorical questions should I ask to make it more impactful during the debate?
Would the Literature teacher let us play board games instead? I probably shouldnâ€™t be the one bringing it up since she wasnâ€™t particularly fond of me.
We were in the middle of the game so it would suck if the flow is broken like this.
A board game session typically lasts around 2 hours, but some teachers were flexible enough to let us play through. Thatâ€™s why I had the Audacity to consider asking in the first place, though not all were as accommodating.

A Regime That Should Have Been Universal
The educational autonomy level I got was unprecedentedly and inimitably high, along with a hefty budget for students.
We had the freedom to decide how to spend our time, with a monthly salary exceeding a million â€”a huge amount back then,  far more than one student could reasonably spendâ€” for basically existing.
Students who lived a bit off the beaten track would earn almost twice as much.
Big monetary rewards were given (around 9.000.000â‚« per semester per student) for getting an 8.5 GPA, which was not hard, at all.
The schoolâ€™s monthly budget for us was roughly 2 billion VND, as stated by the headmaster.
Amidst all this, the school policy was:

If you wanted to play, play. If you wanted to learn, learn.

By all means, that was the best thing since sliced bread for me.
I got the habit of playing truant since the regulations are so flexible and open. You got to decide whatâ€™s next for you; the temptation level is obviously off the chart for a student, you see.
I could attend only half the lessons (usually two) in the morning, go to the net to play video games, skip the afternoon lecture, and go to the coffee shop with my friends, who would skip as well.
When I first got admitted, I did this a lot, with leading repercussions, of courseâ€¦ Still, I am lucky enough to have many friends of the same frequency who would do those silly stuff with me and make so much memories, yet I could recount them like the back of my hand.
Each class is financially independent, covering its own bills for electricity, water, and cleaning.
We had a 65â€™ touchscreen TV, 2 pairs of JBL Speakers in the name of learning listening ğŸ˜‚, and lots of mics ğŸ¤ğŸ¤ğŸ¤.
We even bought a pine tree and snow-dry ice dispenser for Christmas.
Every day was either karaoke or movie day with mixed board games and debate contests (a type of roleplay with two opposing teams in parliamentary style, regarding local issues to international dilemmas).
Karaoke was almost an indispensable daily activity, or at least I made it so.
We all shared the same music taste and could jam to the beat forever, do headbang, and even pull off dance covers. The stage was almost always overcrowded.
Despite all the temptations that might have been, the biggest one was not coming to class and missing out on something. I stopped playing truant, more or less.
We traveled a lot, even by plane once, to various provinces in Vietnam. We even got to spend 4 days in Da Nang during the fireworks season; thatâ€™s when I won my 3rd girlfriend, a.k.a current bff, over as well, making it kinda memorable for me. Needless to say, looking back, everything is full of laughter, thrills, and endless singing ğŸµ ğŸ¶ğŸµ.
Thatâ€™s probably why I love karaoke; it feels like stepping into a bittersweet simulation. Though itâ€™s never quite the same, the experience always brings back those core memories subconsciously in the best way.
Nostalgia hits hard ğŸ¥ºğŸ˜¢
Bittersweet Epiphany
From what I can recall, everyone was innocent and carefree in a sense, embracing every passing moment without the slightest care in the world.
The inquiry of what would become of us, or what our hopes and dreams for the future were, never crossed our daily train of thought. Yet Iâ€™m certain they will become the brightest people I know; some already are and are on the brink of refining their identities.
I can still remember that feeling, vaguely - the way dreaming came as naturally as breathing. Just now, I remember someone from those days gave us a name: ğŸŒ±LÃ¡mer.
For me, high school was when the seed of my fantasies and aspirations was planted, and the mold of my true self was finalized, all stemming from those naive and untroubled experiences. None of what I have achieved, or will achieve, could have happened without those everlasting moments when we could afford to be dreamers. Those fleeting, precious  days shaped our dreams and life trajectories, allowing us to envision a future filled with endless possibilities.
Why do I tell you all this? Why not?
I realized some time ago that the privileges I received should not be taken for granted, as I wouldnâ€™t trade them for anything.
Now, I see them as something I have to bear on my shoulders, my responsibilities. The spark of life ğŸŒŸI received is something I long to share, driven by both my sense of obligation and wholeheartedness.
Passing The Torch ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥
Back in the days, my mother brought up the idea that I should take on teaching as a profession. I used to despise that so much, claiming I hated teaching without any real reasonâ€”I still donâ€™t know why I said that.
Ironically enough, I started tutoring in 12th grade, have had more than 100 students, and now you guys are my next endeavors.
With hindsight, my mom was quite a prophet, nhá»‰?
I often tell students about my teachers,  who put me on the right track even when I had strayed far from itâ€”which fact never mattered to them.
I owe a great deal to my life sabers for guiding me during times I needed it most, even without realizing it at the time.
I realized that many kids would have been a lot better off had they met the teachers I once had, those who have the most unconventional methods that I can somewhat fathom now.
My very first students were forced upon me as favors asked by relatives, leaving me with little room for decline. Slowly but surely, teaching had crept up on me and intrigued me as I saw the growth and influence it can have on both parties.
Even though Iâ€™m still learning, I feel like Iâ€™ve got a lot to share.

Sharing Is Caring.

Knowledge isnâ€™t meant to be hoarded like treasure â€” itâ€™s meant to flow freely, like water. Iâ€™ve been fortunate enough to stumble upon this cheat code, and it would be selfish to keep it to myself.
Cheat Code For Life
I believe I possess a wide spectrum of emotions and strong knowledge utilization and I attribute this sort of accomplishment largely to learning languages.
Out of all the skills Iâ€™ve learned, learning English has been my ultimate cheat code. I see it as a bridge that connects me to anywhere, any souls across cultures.
I still remember the first time I heard lyrics in a language not my mother tongue, yet they resonated deeply. I had butterflies in my stomach, a sadness so profound that it wrenched my heart. That feeling when words echo straight to the heart, not the brain â€” I felt like discovering an entirely new part of myself.
Then, the new refreshing experiences kept flowing: breaking down in tears watching movies, giggling at random jokes in the comments, discovering beauty hidden between the lines, having words spiraling out of your mind that you didnâ€™t know were in your possession, and finally seeing the payoff of your efforts.
From the moment I can proudly claim English as my second language, I felt like I got a master key that unlock virtually every door. Iâ€™ve walked in the shoes of people from different corners of the world, sharing nothing but a common language, yet it was enough to foster both sympathy and empathy.
Each conversation, each perspective shared, reshapes my understanding of the world. With the advent of the Internet, itâ€™s like having multiple lives in parallel: experiencing countless joys, struggles, triumphs, and so many unnamed emotions through the eyes of people Iâ€™ve never met. Truly a cheat code.
While this might seem commonplace to some, we fell into the category of those who werenâ€™t entitled to it.
It upsets and frustrates me to see so many may forever remain ignorant of the potential of their growth had they known a few more things.
The foreign viewpoint that reduces a language to merely a subject exists only because they havenâ€™t witnessed its miracles â€” how it can transform your outlook overnight.
What they dismiss as â€œjust Englishâ€ is actually a portal to infinite glitches: to friendships that span continents, to knowledge that hasnâ€™t been translated or better yet translated into this most accessible language, to perspectives that challenge everything you know, to opportunities that others canâ€™t ever fathom.
They havenâ€™t yet realized that a language isnâ€™t just a tool for communicationâ€”itâ€™s a lens through which to view the world, a key to unlock different versions of yourself simultaneously, to experience the cultural and personality subtle shift as you switch language, and ultimately to a more prosperous eye-opening life.
If you have faith in yourself and trust in me:

Those desired objectives will become your realities.

Whatâ€™s Next?
Now, you have familiarized yourself with your teacher. Letâ€™s move on to the class guidelines.

Weekly Routine

Active Listening Skills

Avoid distractions: put phone away, clear desk

nums = numbers

Listen for direction words first (north, south, left, right)

Materials/Quizzes/present-tense-quiz.title: Present Tense Review Quiz
Materials/Quizzes/present-tense-quiz.content:
Present Tense Review Quiz
Quiz Settings

Time Limit: 45 minutes
Points: 100
Attempts Allowed: 2

Questions
Question 1
Type: multiple_choice
Points: 20
Question: Choose the correct form of the verb for the sentence: â€œMy brother _____ basketball every weekend.â€

 play
 plays
 playing
 are playing

Question 2
Type: text_entry
Points: 30
Question: Complete this sentence using the present continuous tense: â€œRight now, I _____â€ (use the verb â€œlearnâ€)
Answer: Right now, I am learning English.
Question 3
Type: matching
Points: 25
Question: Match the subjects with their correct present simple verb forms:

The cat | sleeps
I | sleep
You | sleep
They | sleep
She | sleeps

Question 4
Type: essay
Points: 25
Question: Write a paragraph describing your typical morning routine using present simple tense.
Instructions:

Use at least 5 different verbs
Include time expressions (e.g., always, usually, sometimes)
Write 4-5 sentences
Pay attention to third-person singular (he/she/it) verb forms

Vocabulary/A-Pinch-Of-Salt.content:
a pinch of salt
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to not completely believe something that you are told, because you think it is unlikely to be true:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


You have to take everything she says with a pinch of salt, because she tends to exaggerate.

index.title: Introduction
index.content:
Greetings, Family
Our class will begin this week, I hope that we will have a smooth sailing journey together.
A Personal Note
First, this is deeply personal for me, and I trusted you guys to keep this between us, so DO NOT share with anyone, okay? Even though itâ€™s on public domain :D
Typically, I would jot down these reflections in my journal but for this occasion, to motivate you guys, to hopefully ignite a flame of undying passion for learning, I would like to share a snapshot of my life. First, one of my early mottos:

My thirst for knowledge will never be quenched.

If you donâ€™t like it, then tough luck, take this as a reading task, and Iâ€™ve highlighted the vocabulary that youâ€™ve learned, not the new ones.
So, to mark the commencement of our learning endeavor, here are your first tasks:


                  
                  This week's tasks 
                  
                


  First-level of recursion for new words on this reading task.
 Your comments/remarks (at least 3), send me personally or via group chat, suit you.
 Extra 2 points for those who note grammar structures used as well. An exhaustive one.



âš ï¸Note  Minus 1 point for each vocabulary word you miss if asked. Missing means that you havenâ€™t noted it yet.
Autobiography
People often tell me how â€œa normal personâ€ would behave differently than I do, so I guess itâ€™s only reasonable that my school life wasnâ€™t typical either, lol.
Compared to my peers, I didnâ€™t study as much, playing most of the time and often doing the bare minimum or finding unconventional shortcuts to keep pace with them. But lucky me, the so-called â€œpeersâ€ were all geniuses, so I got put in place a lot. Even if I fooled around, the baseline level of effort to keep up helped me pass almost every important test entry.
My life has been the complete opposite and will probably become of this quote:

You either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.


Without any intervention, wandering with perplexity and curiosity, I turned into a bad, but meticulous kid that no one seemed to notice.


I believe the duality of oneâ€™s nature will always be present, but my poor decisions were taken lightly, or more accurately, went by unawares.
Iâ€™m not proud, but thankfully, I could get back on the right track without much of a fight.

Primary School
This period was what I called â€œA Dark Era,â€ a time filled with confusion and all sorts of emotions with no self-awareness and restraint.
I was a perfect role model student and, better yet, a bully.
Too sharp for my own good, excelling at anything I picked up, so naturally, I got things in my favor.
Peopleâ€™s attention and praise probably took a heavy toll on me, feeding an ego that I didnâ€™t know how to process, but that was no excuse. I was led astray, blinded by the rewards and recognition.
Maybe subtle blame for uncontrollable primal instinctsâ€”aggression, violence, and the desperate need for validation.ğŸ˜Œ
Letâ€™s not delve furtherâ€¦
Secondary School
The Muted Aftermath
A got-away-with-it-somehow spoiled brat ended up in the top class of the top secondary school. I came to my senses only much later on, back then I was still feigning ignorance and acting on impulse, as most children would.
The school wasnâ€™t too far from my house, but still far enough for a kid to go on his own, and my parents couldnâ€™t drop me off either.
Therefore, I got this uncalled-for luxury of going to school by taxiâ€”yep, a taxi, alongside my neighborhood friends. Truly a story to be bragging about, for bourgeois families.
The academic life went south from here ğŸ˜… as the impetuous desires got the better of me. I skipped classes more than I skipped meals.
I would told the cab driver to stop by the net on the way to school =))) and he would happily do so, since he was paid. Not my kid, not my problem ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ Gotta respect that attitude. Had a lot of fun and a lot of bad gradesâ€¦ Everything was on a downward spiral, yet funny enough, I never got caught or confronted.
Underappreciated Youth
I formed bonds with most of my closest friends here with the most unfiltered, raw, and rough version of myself. The same goes for them.
These low-maintenance relationships, I believe, will stay unstained, growing stronger yet unaffected by time and distance as it has always been.
We were not only in the best but also the wealthiest class. We could go on weekend trips if any of the generous parents were happy that their kid scored a 10. A local prize would almost guarantee a trip and a national one!? Weâ€™d have back-to-back class holidays! Without spending a dime.
This seemingly chill class turned out to have the highest unprecedented acceptance rate at Lam Son Gifted High School.
I doubt Iâ€™ll ever have as many extravagant field trips as I did back then. I got to see so much of Vietnamâ€™s beauty and historical richness â€” things I had long taken for granted.
But it wasnâ€™t just the scenes and places I overlooked; it was the people too. I discovered so many new emotionsâ€”ones that were pivotal, inevitable, but bitterishâ€”regret, sorrow, rage, and that heartbroken feeling, or whatever youâ€™d name it.
Most of these feelings were directed at myself: for the decisions I left unmade, for the precious people I failed to cherish until they quietly walked out of my life forever.
Though painful, these realizations became the compass points guiding my future path and were the turning point for me.
High School
Getting into Lam Son has been my most significant cornerstone, though I didnâ€™t realize it only until recently.
It wasnâ€™t the schoolâ€™s prestige or education (which, in and of itself, is remarkable) that made the differenceâ€”it was the people here who changed me for the better, forever.
My typical day here would start like this:

Iâ€™d wake up late and rush to school, couldnâ€™t make it on time, thinking â€œscrew it,â€ and go buy breakfast with extra, extra toppings, leisurely enjoying every bite.
I was the class secretary, so it was easy for me to make up a lot of excuses for my 15-to-30-minute tardiness. I did this so frequently that everyone gradually stopped questioning my legitimacy.
Getting away with it almost every time - the pinnacle of gaslighting, huh?

The daily inquiries were rather simple:

What should I eat next?
Where should we hang out after school?
Should we play Werewolves, Ribbit, or Exploding Kittens today?
What rhetorical questions should I ask to make it more impactful during the debate?
Would the Literature teacher let us play board games instead? I probably shouldnâ€™t be the one bringing it up since she wasnâ€™t particularly fond of me.
We were in the middle of the game so it would suck if the flow is broken like this.
A board game session typically lasts around 2 hours, but some teachers were flexible enough to let us play through. Thatâ€™s why I had the Audacity to consider asking in the first place, though not all were as accommodating.

A Regime That Should Have Been Universal
The educational autonomy level I got was unprecedentedly and inimitably high, along with a hefty budget for students.
We had the freedom to decide how to spend our time, with a monthly salary exceeding a million â€”a huge amount back then,  far more than one student could reasonably spendâ€” for basically existing.
Students who lived a bit off the beaten track would earn almost twice as much.
Big monetary rewards were given (around 9.000.000â‚« per semester per student) for getting an 8.5 GPA, which was not hard, at all.
The schoolâ€™s monthly budget for us was roughly 2 billion VND, as stated by the headmaster.
Amidst all this, the school policy was:

If you wanted to play, play. If you wanted to learn, learn.

By all means, that was the best thing since sliced bread for me.
I got the habit of playing truant since the regulations are so flexible and open. You got to decide whatâ€™s next for you; the temptation level is obviously off the chart for a student, you see.
I could attend only half the lessons (usually two) in the morning, go to the net to play video games, skip the afternoon lecture, and go to the coffee shop with my friends, who would skip as well.
When I first got admitted, I did this a lot, with leading repercussions, of courseâ€¦ Still, I am lucky enough to have many friends of the same frequency who would do those silly stuff with me and make so much memories, yet I could recount them like the back of my hand.
Each class is financially independent, covering its own bills for electricity, water, and cleaning.
We had a 65â€™ touchscreen TV, 2 pairs of JBL Speakers in the name of learning listening ğŸ˜‚, and lots of mics ğŸ¤ğŸ¤ğŸ¤.
We even bought a pine tree and snow-dry ice dispenser for Christmas.
Every day was either karaoke or movie day with mixed board games and debate contests (a type of roleplay with two opposing teams in parliamentary style, regarding local issues to international dilemmas).
Karaoke was almost an indispensable daily activity, or at least I made it so.
We all shared the same music taste and could jam to the beat forever, do headbang, and even pull off dance covers. The stage was almost always overcrowded.
Despite all the temptations that might have been, the biggest one was not coming to class and missing out on something. I stopped playing truant, more or less.
We traveled a lot, even by plane once, to various provinces in Vietnam. We even got to spend 4 days in Da Nang during the fireworks season; thatâ€™s when I won my 3rd girlfriend, a.k.a current bff, over as well, making it kinda memorable for me. Needless to say, looking back, everything is full of laughter, thrills, and endless singing ğŸµ ğŸ¶ğŸµ.
Thatâ€™s probably why I love karaoke; it feels like stepping into a bittersweet simulation. Though itâ€™s never quite the same, the experience always brings back those core memories subconsciously in the best way.
Nostalgia hits hard ğŸ¥ºğŸ˜¢
Bittersweet Epiphany
From what I can recall, everyone was innocent and carefree in a sense, embracing every passing moment without the slightest care in the world.
The inquiry of what would become of us, or what our hopes and dreams for the future were, never crossed our daily train of thought. Yet Iâ€™m certain they will become the brightest people I know; some already are and are on the brink of refining their identities.
I can still remember that feeling, vaguely - the way dreaming came as naturally as breathing. Just now, I remember someone from those days gave us a name: ğŸŒ±LÃ¡mer.
For me, high school was when the seed of my fantasies and aspirations was planted, and the mold of my true self was finalized, all stemming from those naive and untroubled experiences. None of what I have achieved, or will achieve, could have happened without those everlasting moments when we could afford to be dreamers. Those fleeting, precious  days shaped our dreams and life trajectories, allowing us to envision a future filled with endless possibilities.
Why do I tell you all this? Why not?
I realized some time ago that the privileges I received should not be taken for granted, as I wouldnâ€™t trade them for anything.
Now, I see them as something I have to bear on my shoulders, my responsibilities. The spark of life ğŸŒŸI received is something I long to share, driven by both my sense of obligation and wholeheartedness.
Passing The Torch ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥
Back in the days, my mother brought up the idea that I should take on teaching as a profession. I used to despise that so much, claiming I hated teaching without any real reasonâ€”I still donâ€™t know why I said that.
Ironically enough, I started tutoring in 12th grade, have had more than 100 students, and now you guys are my next endeavors.
With hindsight, my mom was quite a prophet, nhá»‰?
I often tell students about my teachers,  who put me on the right track even when I had strayed far from itâ€”which fact never mattered to them.
I owe a great deal to my life sabers for guiding me during times I needed it most, even without realizing it at the time.
I realized that many kids would have been a lot better off had they met the teachers I once had, those who have the most unconventional methods that I can somewhat fathom now.
My very first students were forced upon me as favors asked by relatives, leaving me with little room for decline. Slowly but surely, teaching had crept up on me and intrigued me as I saw the growth and influence it can have on both parties.
Even though Iâ€™m still learning, I feel like Iâ€™ve got a lot to share.

Sharing Is Caring.

Knowledge isnâ€™t meant to be hoarded like treasure â€” itâ€™s meant to flow freely, like water. Iâ€™ve been fortunate enough to stumble upon this cheat code, and it would be selfish to keep it to myself.
Cheat Code For Life
